Name: Augustus IMPERATOR CAESAR DIVI FILIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Great-nephew and adopted son of  Julius Caesar ; became  de facto  emperor as a result of the 'first settlement' between himself and the  Roman Senate .

Name: Tiberius TIBERIVS  CAESAR DIVI AVGVSTI FILIVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Natural son of  Livia Drusilla , Augustus' third wife, by a previous marriage; stepbrother and third husband of  Julia the Elder , daughter of Augustus; adopted by Augustus as his son and heir.
Deaths: 16 March 37 AD (aged 77) Probably natural causes, possibly assassinated by Caligula or praetorian prefect  Naevius Sutorius Macro

Name: Caligula GAIVS IVLIVS CAESAR AVGVSTVS GERMANICVS
Succession: Great-nephew and adoptive grandson of Tiberius; natural son of  Germanicus ; great-grandson of Augustus.
Deaths: 24 January 41 AD (aged 28) Assassinated in a conspiracy involving senators and  Praetorian Guards

Name: Claudius TIBERIVS  CLAVDIVS  CAESAR AVGVSTVS GERMANICVS
Succession: Uncle of Caligula; brother of Germanicus; nephew of Tiberius; great-nephew and step-grandson of Augustus; proclaimed emperor by the  Praetorian Guard .
Deaths: 13 October 54 AD (aged 63) Probably poisoned by his wife  Agrippina the Younger , in favour of her son Nero, possibly natural causes

Name: Nero NERO  CLAVDIVS CAESAR AVGVSTVS GERMANICVS
Succession: Great-nephew, stepson, son-in-law and adopted son of Claudius; nephew of Caligula; great-great-nephew of Tiberius; grandson of Germanicus; great-great-grandson of Augustus
Deaths: 9 June 68 AD (aged 30) Committed suicide after being declared a public enemy by the Senate

Name: Galba SERVIVS  GALBA  IMPERATOR CAESAR AVGVSTVS
Succession: Seized power after Nero's suicide, with support of the Praetorian Guard
Deaths: 15 January 69 AD (aged 72) Murdered by  Praetorian Guard  in coup led by Otho

Name: Otho IMPERATOR MARCVS  OTHO  CAESAR AVGVSTVS
Succession: Appointed by Praetorian Guard
Deaths: 16 April 69 AD (aged 36) Committed suicide after losing  Battle of Bedriacum  to Vitellius

Name: Vitellius AVLVS  VITELLIVS  GERMANICVS IMPERATOR AVGVSTVS
Succession: Seized power with support of  German Legions  (in opposition to Galba/Otho)
Deaths: 20 December 69 AD (aged 54) Murdered by  Vespasian 's troops

Name: Vespasian IMPERATOR CAESAR  VESPASIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Seized power with the support of the eastern Legions (in opposition to Marcillinus)

Name: Titus IMPERATOR  TITVS  CAESAR VESPASIANVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Vespasian

Name: Domitian IMPERATOR CAESAR  DOMITIANVS  AVGVSTVS GERMANICVS
Succession: Brother of Titus; son of Vespasian
Deaths: 18 September 96 AD (aged 44) Assassinated by court officials

Name: Nerva IMPERATOR  NERVA  CAESAR AVGVSTVS
Succession: Appointed by the  Senate . First of the " Five Good Emperors ".

Name: Trajan IMPERATOR CAESAR NERVA  TRAIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Adopted son and heir of Nerva. His reign marked the geographical peak of the empire

Name: Hadrian IMPERATOR CAESAR TRAIANVS  HADRIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Adopted son and heir of Trajan

Name: Antoninus Pius IMPERATOR CAESAR TITVS AELIVS HADRIANVS  ANTONINVS  AVGVSTVS  PIVS
Succession: Adopted son and heir of Hadrian

Name: Lucius Verus IMPERATOR CAESAR  LVCIVS  AVRELIVS  VERVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Adopted son and heir of Antoninus Pius and son-in-law of Marcus Aurelius; Co-emperor with Marcus Aurelius until his death

Name: Marcus Aurelius IMPERATOR CAESAR  MARCVS AVRELIVS  ANTONINVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Adopted son, son-in-law and heir of Antoninus Pius; Co-emperor with Lucius Verus until 169. Last of the " Five Good Emperors "

Name: Commodus IMPERATOR CAESAR LUCIVS AELIVS AVRELIVS  COMMODVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Natural son of Marcus Aurelius; joint emperor from 177
Time: 3 years as joint emperor, 12 years as sole emperor
Deaths:
31 December 192 (aged 31)
 Assassinated in palace, strangled in his bath

Name: Pertinax IMPERATOR CAESAR PVBLIVS HELVIVS  PERTINAX  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor by Praetorian Guard

Name: Didius Julianus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS  DIDIVS  SEVERVS  IVLIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Won auction held by the Praetorian Guard for the position of emperor
Deaths: 1 June 193 (aged 56 or 60) Executed on orders of the Senate

Name: Septimius Severus IMPERATOR CAESAR LVCIVS  SEPTIMIVS SEVERVS  EVSEBES PERTINAX AVGVSTVS
Succession: Seized power with support of  Pannonian  legions [a]

Name: Caracalla IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS  ANTONINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Septimius Severus; co-emperor with Severus from 198; with Severus and Geta from 209 until February 211; co-emperor with Geta until December 211
Time: 13 years as joint emperor 10 months with Geta 6 years as sole emperor
Deaths: 8 April 217 (aged 29) Murdered by a soldier as part of a conspiracy involving  Macrinus

Name: Geta IMPERATOR CAESAR PVBLIVS SEPTIMIVS  CETA  AVGVSTUS
Succession: Son of Septimius Severus; co-emperor with Severus and Caracalla from 209 until February 211; co-emperor with Caracalla until December 211
Time: 2 years as joint emperor 10 months with Caracalla
Deaths: 26 December 211 (aged 22) Murdered on the orders of Caracalla

Name:
Macrinus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS OPELLIVS SEVERVS  MACRINVS  AVGVSTVS with Diadumenian 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS OPELLIVS ANTONINVS  DIADVMENIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Praetorian Prefect  to Caracalla, probably conspired to have Caracalla murdered and proclaimed himself emperor after Caracalla's death; made his son Diadumenian (born on 14 September 208) co-emperor in May 218
Deaths: 8 June 218 (aged 53) Both executed in favour of Elagabalus

Name: Elagabalus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS ANTONINVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Grandnephew of Septimius Severus, first cousin once removed and alleged illegitimate son of Caracalla; proclaimed emperor by  Syrian legions

Name: Severus Alexander IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS  SEVERVS ALEXANDER  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Grandnephew of Septimius Severus, cousin and adoptive heir of Elagabalus

Name: Maximinus Thrax IMPERATOR CAESAR GAIVS IVLIVS VERVS  MAXIMINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor by Germanic legions after the murder of Severus Alexander
Deaths: June 238 (aged 65) Assassinated by his men during the  siege of Aquileia

Name: Gordian I IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS ANTONIVS  CORDIANVS  SEMPRONIANVS ROMANVS AFRICANVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor, whilst Pro-consul in  Africa , during a revolt against Maximinus. Ruled jointly with his son Gordian II, and in opposition to Maximinus. Technically a usurper, but retrospectively legitimised by the accession of Gordian III
Deaths: April 238 (aged 79) Committed suicide upon hearing of the death of Gordian II.

Name: Gordian II IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS ANTONIVS  CORDIANVS  SEMPRONIANVS ROMANVS AFRICANVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor, alongside father Gordian I, in opposition to Maximinus by act of the Senate.
Deaths: April 238 (aged 46) Killed during the  Battle of Carthage , fighting a pro-Maximinus army

Name: Pupienus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS CLODIVS  PVPIENVS  MAXIMVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed joint emperor with Balbinus by the Senate in opposition to Maximinus; later co-emperor with Balbinus.
Deaths: July 29, 238 (aged 68 or 73) Assassinated by the Praetorian Guard

Name: Balbinus IMPERATOR CAESAR DECIMVS CAELIVS CALVINVS  BALBINVS  PIVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed joint emperor with Pupienus by the  Senate  after death of Gordian I and II, in opposition to Maximinus; later co-emperor with Pupienus and Gordian III

Name: Gordian III IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS ANTONIVS  CORDIANVS  PIVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor by supporters of Gordian I and II, then by the Senate; joint emperor with Pupienus and Balbinus until July 238; grandson and nephew of Gordian I and II, respectively
Deaths: February 11, 244 (aged 19) Unknown; possibly murdered on orders of Philip I

Name:
Philip the Arab IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS IVLIVS  PHILIPPVS  AVGVSTVS with 
 Philip II 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS IVLIVS SEVERVS  PHILLIPVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Praetorian Prefect  to Gordian III, took power after his death; made his son Philip II (born 237) co-emperor in summer 247
Deaths: September/October 249 (aged 45) Killed in the  Battle of Verona  by Decius, Philip II murdered by the Praetorian Guard

Name:
Decius IMPERATOR CAESAR CAIVS MESSIVS QVINTVS TRAIANVS  DECIVS  AVGVSTVS with 
 Herennius Etruscus 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR QVINTVS  HERENNIVS ETRVSCVS  MESSIVS DECIVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Governor under Philip the Arab; proclaimed emperor by  Danubian legions  then defeating and killing Philip in the Battle of Verona; made his son Herennius Etruscus (born 227) co-emperor in early 251
Deaths: June 251 (aged 50) Both killed in the  Battle of Abrittus  fighting against the  Goths

Name: Hostilian IMPERATOR CAESAR CAIVS VALENS  HOSTILIANVS  MESSIVS QVINTVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Decius, accepted as heir by the  Senate

Name:
Trebonianus Gallus IMPERATOR CAESAR GAIVS VIBIVS AFINIVS  TREBONIANVS GALLVS  AVGVSTVS with 
 Volusianus 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR GAIVS VIBIVS  VOLVSIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Governor of  Moesia Superior , proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions after Decius's death (and in opposition to Hostilian); made his son Volusianus co-emperor in late 251.
Deaths: August 253 (aged 47) Assassinated by their own troops, in favour of  Aemilian

Name: Aemilian IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AEMILIVS  AEMILIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Governor of  Moesia Superior , proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions after defeating the  Goths ; accepted as emperor after death of Gallus
Deaths: September/October 253 (aged 40 or 46) Assassinated by his own troops, in favour of Valerian

Name: Valerian IMPERATOR CAESAR PVBLIVS LICINIVS  VALERIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Governor of  Noricum  and  Raetia , proclaimed emperor by Rhine legions after death of Gallus; accepted as emperor after death of Aemilian
Deaths: After 260 (aged at least 65) Captured in  Battle of Edessa  against  Persians , died in captivity

Name:
Gallienus IMPERATOR CAESAR PVBLIVS LICINIVS EGNATIVS  GALLIENVS  AVGVSTVS with 
 Saloninus 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR CORNELIVS LICINIVS  SALONINVS  VALERIANVS PIVS FELIX INVICTVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Valerian, made co-emperor in 253; his son Saloninus (born c. 242) is very briefly co-emperor in c. July 260 before assassination by  Postumus .
Deaths: September 268 (aged 50) Murdered at  Aquileia  by his own commanders.

Name: Claudius Gothicus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS VALERIVS  CLAVDIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Victorious general at  Battle of Naissus , seized power after Gallienus's death

Name: Quintillus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS CLAVDIVS  QVINTILLVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Brother of Claudius II, seized power after his death
Deaths: 270 (aged around 60) Unclear; possibly suicide or murder

Name: Aurelian IMPERATOR CAESAR LVCIVS DOMITIVS  AVRELIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions after Claudius II's death, in opposition to Quintillus

Name: Ulpia Severina  (possibly)  VLPIA SEVERINA  PIA AVGVSTA
Succession: Wife of Aurelian, numismatic evidence gave rise to the speculation that she ruled in her own right during the  interregnum  between Aurelian's death and the election of Tacitus. [10] [11]

Name: Tacitus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS CLAVDIVS  TACITVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Elected by the  Senate  to replace Aurelian, after a short  interregnum

Name: Florianus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS ANNIVS  FLORIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Brother of Tacitus, elected by the army in the west to replace him
Deaths: September? 276 (aged ?) Assassinated by his own troops, in favour of Probus

Name: Probus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS  PROBVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Governor of the eastern provinces, proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions in opposition to  Florian
Deaths: September/ October 282 (aged 50) Assassinated by his own troops, in favour of  Carus

Name: Carus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS  CARVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Praetorian Prefect to Probus; seized power either before or after Probus was murdered; made his son Carinus co-emperor in early 283
Reign: September/ October 282 – late July/ early August 283
Deaths: Late July/August 283 (aged 61) Probably natural causes (Possibly killed by lightning)

Name: Carinus CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS  CARINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Carus, ruled shortly with him (from early 283) as co-emperor and then in his own right with his brother Numerian
Deaths: 285 (aged ?) Probably died in battle against Diocletian

Name: Numerian IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS NVMERIVS  NVMERIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Carus, succeeded him jointly with his brother Carinus

Name:
Diocletian IMPERATOR CAESAR CAIVS AVRELIVS VALERIVS  DIOCLETIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST   and  WEST) 
 then, after 286 
 (EAST)
Succession: Proclaimed emperor by army after death of  Numerian , and in opposition to  Carinus ; adopted  Maximian  as senior co-emperor in 286
Deaths: 3 December 311 (aged 67) Abdicated; died of natural causes in  Aspalatos

Name:
Maximian IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS VALERIVS  MAXIMIANVS  HERCVLIVS AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Adopted as senior co-emperor ('Augustus') in the west by Diocletian in 286
Deaths: 310 (aged 60) Abdicated with Diocletian; twice tried to regain throne with, and then from Maxentius; captured by Constantine I and committed suicide at his behest

Name:
Galerius IMPERATOR CAESAR GAIVS  GALERIVS  VALERIVS MAXIMIANVS AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST)
Succession: Adopted as junior co-emperor ('Caesar') and heir by Diocletian in 293. Also son-in-law of Diocletian.

Name:
Constantius Chlorus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS FLAVIVS VALERIVS  CONSTANTIVS  HERCVLIVS AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Adopted as junior co-emperor ('Caesar') and heir by Maximian in 293

Name:
Valerius Severus IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  VALERIVS SEVERVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Adopted as junior co-emperor ('Caesar') and heir by Constantius Chlorus in 305; succeeded as Augustus in 306; opposed by Maxentius and Constantine I
Deaths: September 16, 307 (aged ?) Captured by Maxentius and forced to commit suicide (or murdered)

Name:
Constantine the Great (Constantine I) IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS VALERIVS AVRELIVS  CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS  
 
 (WEST) 
 then, after 324 
 (EAST   and  WEST)
Succession: Son of Constantius I Chlorus, proclaimed emperor by his father's troops; accepted as Caesar (west) by Galerius in 306; promoted to Augustus (west) in 307 by Maximian after death of Severus II; refused relegation to Caesar in 309

Name:
Maxentius IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS AVRELIVS VALERIVS  MAXENTIVS  AVGVSTVS  
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Son of Maximian, seized power in 306 after death of Constantius I Chlorus, in opposition to Severus and Constantine I; made Caesar (west) by Maximian in 307 after the death of Severus
Deaths: October 28, 312 (aged 36) Died at the  Battle of the Milvian Bridge , against Constantine I

Name:
Licinius IMPERATOR CAESAR CAIVS VALERIVS LICINIANVS  LICINIVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST) w ith 
 Valerius Valens 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR AVRELIVS  VALERIVS VALENS  AVGVSTVS 
 and 
 Martinian 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR SEXTVS MARCIVS  MARTININANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Constantius Chlorus, appointed Augustus in the west by Galerius in 308, in opposition to Maxentius; became Augustus in the east in 311 after the death of Galerius (shared with Maximinus II); defeated Maximinus II in civil war to become sole eastern Augustus in 313; appointed Valerius Valens in 317, and Martinian in 324 as western Augustus, in opposition to Constantine, both being executed within weeks.
Deaths: 325 (aged 61/62) Defeated in civil war against Constantine I in 324 and captured; executed on the orders of Constantine the next year

Name:
Maximinus II IMPERATOR CAESAR CAIVS CALERIVS VALERIVS  MAXIMINVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST)
Succession: Nephew of Galerius, adopted as Caesar and his heir in 305; succeeded as Augustus (shared with Licinius I) in 311
Deaths: July/August 313 (aged 42) Defeated in civil war against Licinius; probably committed suicide thereafter

Name:
Constantine II IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS CLAVDIVS  CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Son of Constantine I; appointed Caesar in 317, succeeded as joint Augustus with his brothers Constantius II and Constans I
Deaths: 340 (aged 24) Died in battle against Constans I

Name:
Constantius II IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS IVLIVS  CONSTANTIVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST) 
 then, after 353 
 (EAST  and  WEST)
Succession: Son of Constantine I; succeeded as joint Augustus with his brothers Constantine II and Constans I; sole emperor from 350

Name:
Constans I IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS IVLIVS  CONSTANS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (MIDDLE) 
 then, after 340 
 (WEST)
Succession: Son of Constantine I; succeeded as joint Augustus with his brothers Constantine II and Constantius II
Deaths: 350 (aged 27) Assassinated on the orders of the usurper  Magnentius

Name:
Vetranio IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  VETRANIO  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: General of Constans, proclaimed Caesar against Magnentius and temporarily accepted as Augustus of the west by Constantius II.
Deaths: c. 356 (aged ?) As a private citizen, after abdication.

Name:
Julian IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS CLAVDIVS  IVLIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST) 
 then, after 361 
 (EAST  and  WEST)
Succession: Cousin of Constantius II; made Caesar of the west in 355; proclaimed Augustus by his troops in 360; sole emperor after the death of Constantius

Name:
Jovian IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  IOVIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST  and  WEST)
Succession: General of Julian's army; proclaimed emperor by the troops on Julian's death

Name:
Valentinian I IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  VALENTINIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST  and  WEST) 
 then
 (WEST)
Succession: Elected to replace  Jovian  by the army

Name:
Valens IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS IVLIVS  VALENS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (EAST)
Succession: Brother of  Valentinian I , appointed co-augustus (for the east) by him
Deaths: August 9, 378 (aged 50) Killed in  Battle of Adrianople  against the  Goths

Name:
Gratian IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  GRATIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Son of  Valentinian I , appointed junior Augustus by him in 367, became senior Augustus (for the west) after Valentinian's death.
Deaths: August 25, 383 (aged 24) Murdered by rebellious army faction

Name:
Valentinian II IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  VALENTINIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 (WEST)
Succession: Son of  Valentinian I , proclaimed emperor by Pannonian army after Valentinian's death; accepted as co-Augustus for the west by  Gratian
Deaths: May 15, 392 (aged 21) Unclear; possibly murdered or committed suicide

Name:
Magnus Maximus 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  MAGNVS MAXIMVS  AVGVSTVS 
 (WEST) 
 with 
 Victor 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  VICTOR  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Usurper in the West; legitimized along with his son Victor by  Theodosius I  as emperors of  Britannia  and  Gaul .
Deaths: August 28, 388 (aged 53) Executed by  Theodosius I  in  Aquileia  after the  Battle of the Save ; Victor killed by  Arbogast

Name:
Eugenius 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  EVGENIVS  AVGVSTVS 
 (WEST)
Succession: Usurper in the West; elevated to emperor by  Arbogast .
Deaths: September 6, 394 Executed as a criminal by  Theodosius I  near the  Frigidus river

Name: Theodosius I IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  THEODOSIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Valentinian I, appointed as Augustus for the east by  Gratian  after the death of  Valens ; became sole senior Augustus after death of  Valentinian II  (Eastern Emperor since 379)

Name: Honorius IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  HONORIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of  Theodosius I ; appointed as junior Augustus for the west by Theodosius on January 23, 393 (after the death of  Valentinian II ); became senior Augustus for the west after his father's death

Name:
Constantine III 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS CLAVDIVS  CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS with 
 Constans II 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  CONSTANS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Usurper who declared himself emperor in the west in 407, recognized as co-emperor by  Honorius  in 409. Elevated his son  Constans II  to co-emperor in 409, who was not recognized by Honorius. Neither recognized by the Eastern Empire.
Deaths: August or September 411 (aged ?) Executed by  Constantius III

Name: Constantius III IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  CONSTANTIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Married to  Theodosius I 's daughter  Galla Placidia , elevated to co-Augustus for the west by  Honorius ; not recognized by the  Eastern Empire

Name:
Joannes 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR  IOHANNES  AVGVSTVS
Succession: A senior civil servant under  Honorius , proclaimed emperor by  Castinus ; not recognized by the  Eastern Empire
Deaths: June or July 425 (aged ?) Defeated in battle by  Theodosius II  and  Valentinian III , captured and executed

Name: Valentinian III IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS PLACIDIVS  VALENTINIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of  Constantius III , appointed Caesar for the west by  Theodosius II  after the death of  Honorius , in opposition to the regime of  Joannes ; became Augustus for the west after the defeat of Joannes
Deaths: March 16, 455 (aged 35) Assassinated, possibly at the behest of  Petronius Maximus

Name: Petronius Maximus IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS ANICIVS  PETRONIVS MAXIMVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Theodosius II, proclaimed himself emperor with the support of the army, after the death of  Valentinian III . Not recognized by the  Eastern Empire . He appointed his son  Palladius  as  caesar .
Deaths: May 31, 455 (aged 58/59) Murdered, probably stoned to death by the Roman mob

Name: Avitus IMPERATOR CAESAR MARCVS MAECILIVS FLAVIVS EPARCHIVS  AVITVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Magister militum  under  Petronius Maximus , proclaimed emperor by the  Visigoth  king  Theoderic II  after Petronius's death. Not recognized by the  Eastern Empire .
Deaths: after 17 October 456 (aged 71) Deposed by his  Magister militum ,  Ricimer ; became bishop of  Placentia ; murdered at some point afterwards

Name: Majorian IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS IVLIVS VALERIVS  MAIORIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Proclaimed emperor by his troops. Recognized by the  Eastern Empire  at the behest of  Ricimer .
Deaths: August 7, 461 (aged 40) Deposed and beheaded on the orders of  Ricimer .

Name: Libius Severus IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  LIBIVS SEVERVS  SERPENTIVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Appointed emperor by  Ricimer . Not recognized by the  Eastern Empire .

Name: Anthemius IMPERATOR CAESAR PROCOPIVS  ANTHEMIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Marcian, appointed emperor by  Leo I , with the consent of  Ricimer .
Deaths: July 11, 472 (aged 52) Executed by Ricimer or  Gundobad  (Ricimer's nephew).

Name: Olybrius IMPERATOR CAESAR ANICIVS  OLYBRIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of  Valentinian III ; appointed emperor by  Ricimer . Not recognized by the  Eastern Empire .

Name: Glycerius IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  GLYCERIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Appointed emperor by  Gundobad  ( Ricimer 's successor). Not recognized by the  Eastern Empire .
Deaths: after 480 (aged ?) Deposed by  Julius Nepos , became Bishop of  Salona , time and manner of death unknown

Name: Julius Nepos IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  IVLIVS NEPOS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Nephew-in-law of the eastern emperor  Leo I  (and nephew of  Marcellinus ) appointed emperor in opposition to  Glycerius
Reign: June 474 – August 28, 475 (in Italy); – spring 480 (in Gaul and Dalmatia)
Deaths: 480 (aged 50) Deposed in Italy by  Orestes , ruled in balance of Western Empire until assassination in 480. Maintained as figurehead in Italy by  Odoacer  to his death in 480.

Name: Romulus Augustulus  IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  ROMVLVS AVGVSTVS
Succession: Appointed by his father,  Orestes . Listed as an emperor by historical convention. His rule never extended beyond portions of the  Italian peninsula . Not recognized by Eastern Emperor  Zeno .
Deaths: Unknown. Deposed by  Odoacer , who then ruled in the name of  Julius Nepos  until the latter's death in 480, which formally ended the separate Western Empire; most likely lived out his life in obscurity on a private villa.

Name: Theodosius I IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  THEODOSIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Valentinian I, appointed as Augustus for the east by  Gratian  after the death of  Valens ; became sole senior Augustus after death of  Valentinian II

Name: Arcadius IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  ARCADIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of  Theodosius I ; appointed as junior Augustus for the east by Theodosius in January 383; became senior Augustus for the east after his father's death

Name: Theodosius II IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  THEODOSIVS  IVNIOR AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of  Arcadius ; appointed as junior Augustus for the east by Arcadius in 402; became senior Augustus for the east after his father's death
Deaths: July 28, 450 (aged 49) Injuries suffered during a hunting accident

Name: Marcian IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  MARCIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Nominated as successor (and husband) by  Pulcheria , ruled alongside her 450-453 and later alone

Name: Leo I the Thracian IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS VALERIVS  LEO  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Chosen by the army

Name: Leo II IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  LEO  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Grandson of Leo I

Name: Zeno IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  ZENO  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Named co-emperor by his son Leo II on 9 February 474.

Name:
Basiliscus IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  BASILISCVS  AVGVSTVS 
 
 with 
 Marcus 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  MARCVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Seized throne from Zeno, Basiliscus appointed his son Marcus co-emperor at some point in 475.
Deaths:
476/477
 Starved to death in Limnae (in  Cappadocia ) by Zeno

Name: Anastasius I Dicorus IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  ANASTASIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Leo I

Name: Justin I   IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  IVSTINVS  AVGVSTVS
Birth: c.  450 at Bederiana ( Justiniana Prima ),  Dardania
Succession: Elected by army

Name: Justinian I   IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS PETRVS SABBATIVS  IVSTINIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Nephew of Justin I

Name: Justin II   IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  IVSTINVS  IVNIOR AVGVSTVS
Succession: Nephew of Justinian I

Name:
Tiberius II Constantine 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  TIBERIVS CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Adopted son of Justin II, regent from 574

Name:
Maurice IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  MAURICIVS  TIBERIVS AVGVSTVS 
 
 with 
 Theodosius 
 IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  THEODOSIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son-in-law of Tiberius II, appointed his son Theodosius (born in August 4 583/585) co-emperor in 590
Deaths: 27 November 602 (aged 63) Executed, Theodosius executed a few days later by supporters of Phocas

Name: Phocas IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  PHOCAS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Seized throne

Name: Heraclius (Φλάβιος Ἡράκλειος Αὔγουστος) IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  HERACLIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Revolt

Name: Constantine III (Ἡράκλειος νέος Κωνσταντῖνος Αὔγουστος) IMPERATOR CAESAR HERACLIVS NOVVS  CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Heraclius

Name:
Heraklonas (Φλάβιος Κωνσταντῖνος Ἡράκλειος Αὔγουστος) IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS CONSTANTINVS  HERACLIVS  AVGVSTVS 
 with 
 Tiberius (Φλάβιος Τιβέριος Αὔγουστος) FLAVIVS  TIBERIVS  AVGVSTVS 
 and 
 Martinus (Φλάβιος Μαρτίνος Αὔγουστος) FLAVIVS  MARTINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Heraclius; his brothers Tiberius and Martinus briefly served as co-emperors.

Name: Constans II (Φλάβιος Κωνσταντῖνος Αὔγουστος) IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Constantine III. succeeded his uncle Heraklonas after he was deposed as emperor.

Name:
Constantine IV (Φλάβιος Κωνσταντῖνος Αὔγουστος) IMPERATOR CAESAR FLAVIVS  CONSTANTINVS  AVGVSTVS 
 with 
 Heraclius (Φλάβιος Ἡράκλειος Αὔγουστος) FLAVIVS  HERACLIVS  AVGVSTVS 
 and 
 Tiberius (Φλάβιος Τιβέριος Αὔγουστος) FLAVIVS  TIBERIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Oldest son of Constans II, co-emperor since 654. His brothers Heraclius and Tiberius, co-emperors since 659, served as co-emperors until they were mutilated and deposed by Constantine in 681.

Name: Justinian II (Φλάβιος Ἰουστινιανὸς Αὔγουστος) FLAVIVS  IVSTINIANVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Son of Constantine IV, co-emperor since 681

Name: Leontios (Λεόντιος Αὔγουστος) LEONTIVS  AVGVSTVS [12]
Succession: Revolt

Name: Tiberios III Apsimaros (Τιβέριος Αὔγουστος) TIBERIVS  AVGVSTVS
Succession: Revolt

Name:
Justinian II  (Φλάβιος Ἰουστινιανὸς Αὔγουστος) FLAVIVS  IVSTINIANVS  AVGVSTVS 
 (second reign) 
 with 
 Tiberius (Τιβέριος Αὔγουστος) TIBERIVS  AVGVSTVS [13]
Succession: Returned on the throne with  Bulgar  support. Named son  Tiberius  as co-emperor in 706.
Deaths: 11 December 711 (aged 42) Both killed by the army

Name: Philippikos Bardanes (Φιλιππικὸς Αὔγουστος) FILEPICVS  AVGVSTVS [14]
Succession: Revolt

Name: Anastasios II (Αρτέμιος Ἀναστάσιος Αὔγουστος) ARTEMIVS  ANASTASIVS  AVGVSTVS [15]
Succession: Bureaucrat and secretary under Philippikos, he was raised to the purple by the soldiers
Deaths: 718, during attempt to regain the throne

Name: Theodosius III (Θεοδόσιος Αὔγουστος) THEODOSIVS  AVGVSTVS [16]
Succession: Chosen by troops

Name: Leo III the Isaurian (Λέων)
Succession: Rebellion

Name: Constantine V (Κωνσταντῖνος)
Succession: Son of Leo III

Name:
Artabasdos (Ἀρτάβασδος ) 
 with 
 Nikephoros (Νικηφόρος)
Succession: Son-in-law of Leo III. Usurped throne. Proclaimed his son Nikephoros as co-emperor in 741/742

Name: Leo IV the Khazar (Λέων)
Succession: Son of Constantine V

Name: Constantine VI (Κωνσταντῖνος)
Succession: Son of Leo IV

Name: Irene of Athens (Εἰρήνη)
Succession: Regent  during minority of Constantine VI. Seized throne from son in 797. First Byzantine  empress regnant .

Name: Nikephoros I (Νικηφόρος)
Succession: Rebellion
Deaths: 26 July 811 After the  Battle of Pliska

Name: Staurakios (Σταυράκιος)
Succession: Son of Nikephoros I

Name:
Michael I Rangabe (Μιχαὴλ Ῥαγγαβέ)
 
 with 
 Theophylact 
 (Θεοφύλακτος)
Succession: Son-in-law of Nikephoros I, appointed his son Theophylact (born c. 793) as co-emperor on 25 December 811
Deaths:
January 11 844 (age ~74)
 In a monastery on  Prote Island , Theophylact died in a monastery on  Plate Island  on January 15 849

Name:
Leo V the Armenian (Λέων)
 
 with 
 Constantine 
 (Κωνσταντῖνος)
Succession: Rebellion, appointed his son Symbatios as co-emperor under the name Constantine on Christmas 813
Deaths: 25 December 820 (age ~45) Murdered by successor's conspirators, Constantine died in exile in monastery on  Prote Island  at a later date

Name: Michael II (Μιχαὴλ)
Succession: Chosen after murder of predecessor

Name: Theophilos (Θεόφιλος)
Succession: Only son of Michael II and co-emperor since 821

Name: Michael III (Μιχαὴλ)
Succession: Son of Theophilos

Name: Basil I the Macedonian (Βασίλειος)
Succession: Previous co-emperor, full emperor upon death of predecessor.

Name: Leo VI the Wise (Λέων
Succession: Son of Basil I (potentially in reality the son of Michael III), co-emperor since 870.

Name: Alexander (Ἀλέξανδρος)
Succession: Son of Basil I, co-emperor since 879.
Deaths:
6 June 913 (age 42)
 Exhaustion after a game of  tzykanion

Name: Constantine VII (Κωνσταντῖνος)
Succession: Son of Leo VI, co-emperor since 908.
Deaths:
9 November 959 (age 54), Constantinople
 Possibly poisoned by his son Romanos II

Name:
Romanos I Lekapenos (Ῥωμανὸς Λεκαπηνός)
 
 with 
 Christopher Lekapenos 
 (Χριστόφορος Λακαπηνός)
 and 
 Stephen Lekapenos 
 (Στέφανος Λακαπηνός)
 and 
 Constantine Lekapenos 
 (Κωνσταντίνος Λακαπηνός)
Succession: Regent for the young Constantine VII, crowned himself senior emperor during Constantine VII's minority. Proclaimed his three sons Christopher, Stephen and Constantine as co-emperors. Was overthrown by Stephen in 944, who briefly ruled as senior emperor (for a few weeks) until he himself was overthrown by Constantine VII.
Deaths:
15 June 948 (age 77-78)
 In a monastery as a monk after having been overthrown. Christopher died in August of 931. Both Stephen and Constantine died in exile as monks; Stephen on Easter 963 on  Lesbos  and Constantine in 946-948 on  Samothrace  trying to escape exile and reclaim imperial power

Name: Romanos II (Ῥωμανὸς ὁ Πορφυρογέννητος)
Succession: Son of Constantine VII

Name: Nikephoros II Phokas (Νικηφόρος Φωκᾶς)
Succession: Chosen by the army, acted as senior emperor during the regency of young emperors Basil II and Constantine VIII
Deaths:
11 December 969 (age 56-57), Constantinople
 Assassinated by successor John I Tzimiskes

Name: John I Tzimiskes (Ἰωάννης Τζιμισκής)
Succession: Nephew of Nikephoros II Phokas, succeeded as senior emperor and regent for the young emperors Basil II and Constantine VIII
Deaths:
10 January 976 (age 50-51), Constantinople
 Poisoned by Imperial chamberlain Basil Lekapenos

Name: Basil II (Βασίλειος)
Succession: Eldest son of Romanos II

Name: Constantine VIII (Κωνσταντῖνος ὁ Πορφυρογέννητος)
Succession: Second son of Romanos II, co-emperor since 962.

Name: Zoe Porphyrogenita (Ζωὴ ἡ Πορφυρογέννητη)
Succession: Daughter of Constantine VIII, succeeded on her father's death along with her sister Theodora. Her three husbands, Romanos III (1028–1034), Michael IV (1034–1041) and Constantine IX (1042–1050) ruled alongside her.

Name: Romanos III Argyros (Ῥωμανὸς Ἀργυρός)
Succession: Chosen by Constantine VIII to marry his daughter Zoe and succeed him as emperor.

Name: Michael IV the Paphlagonian (Μιχαὴλ ὁ Παφλαγών)
Succession: Succeeded Romanos III as Zoe's husband and emperor.
Deaths:
10 December 1041 (age 31), Constantinople
 Died after a long illness.

Name: Michael V Kalaphates (Μιχαὴλ ὁ Καλαφάτης)
Succession: Nephew and adopted son of Michael IV.
Deaths:
24 August, 1042 (age 27), Constantinople
 Deposed, blinded, castrated and tonsured after attempting to sideline Zoe and her sister Theodora.

Name: Theodora Porphyrogenita (Θεοδώρα ἡ Πορφυρογέννητος)
Succession: Younger sister of Zoe, raised to co-empress in 1042.
Deaths:
31 August 1056 (age 75-76), Constantinople
 Died after sudden illness.

Name: Constantine IX Monomachos (Κωνσταντῖνος Μονομάχος)
Succession: Zoe's third husband

Name: Michael VI Bringas (Μιχαὴλ Βρίγγας)
Succession: Chosen as successor by Empress Theodora
Deaths: 1059, confined to a monastery after having been deposed by successor.

Name: Isaac I Komnenos (Ἰσαάκιος Κομνηνός)
Succession: Rebellion

Name: Constantine X Doukas (Κωνσταντῖνος Δούκας)
Succession: Chosen successor of Isaac I Komnenos

Name:
Michael VII Doukas (Μιχαὴλ Δούκας)
 
 with 
 Andronikos Doukas 
 (Ἀνδρόνικος Δούκας)
 and 
 Konstantios Doukas 
 (Κωνστάντιος Δούκας)
 and 
 Constantine Doukas 
 (Κωνσταντίνος Δούκας)
Succession: Son of Constantine X Doukas and co-emperor since 1059, resigned the throne in 1078. Reigned alongside his brothers Andronikos and Konstantios as co-emperors. Andronikos died in the 1070s while Konstantios briefly succeeded Michael as senior emperor before being handed over to the usurper Nikephoros III and exiled. Michael's son Constantine was also raised to co-emperor in 1074.
Deaths: 1090 (aged ~40), Constantinople, Konstantios died in the  Battle of Dyrrhachium  on 18 October 1081, having been recalled as a general by Alexios I. Constantine was later raised to co-emperor again under Alexios I and died in 1095

Name: Romanos IV Diogenes (Ῥωμανὸς Διογένης)
Succession: Married to Constantine X's widow and senior emperor as guardian of her sons by Constantine X
Deaths: 1072 (age 42), after having been deposed, blinded and exiled

Name: Nikephoros III Botaneiates (Νικηφόρος Βοτανειάτης)
Succession: Rebellion
Deaths: 10 December 1081 (age 80), after having been deposed and exiled to a monastery

Name:
Alexios I Komnenos (Ἀλέξιος Κομνηνός)
 
 with 
 Constantine Doukas 
 (Κωνσταντίνος Δούκας)
 (second co-emperorship)
Succession: Rebellion, nephew of Isaac I Komnenos, appointed Constantine Doukas (a previous co-emperor under Michael VII) as co-emperor in 1081. Replaced Constantine with his own son John II in 1087.

Name:
John II Komnenos (Ἰωάννης Κομνηνός)
 
 with 
 Alexios Komnenos 
 (Ἀλέξιος Κομνηνός)
Succession: Son of Alexios I, co-emperor since 1087, appointed his son Alexios co-emperor in 1122
Deaths:
8 April 1143 (age 55),  Cilicia 
 Accidentally cut himself on a poisoned arrow. Alexios died in  Attaleia  on 2 August 1142 of a fever

Name: Manuel I Komnenos (Μανουὴλ Κομνηνός)
Succession: Son of John II

Name: Alexios II Komnenos (Ἀλέξιος Κομνηνός)
Succession: Son of Manuel I
Deaths:
October 1183 (age 14), Constantinople
 Deposed and killed by successor

Name:
Andronikos I Komnenos (Ἀνδρόνικος Κομνηνός)
 
 with 
 John Komnenos 
 (Ἰωάννης Κομνηνός)
Succession: Nephew of John II (son of his brother Isaac), uncle of Alexios II, appointed his son John as co-emperor in November 1183
Deaths:
12 September 1185 (age 66-67), Constantinople
 Overthrown and lynched in a popular uprising, John also seized and probably killed

Name: Isaac II Angelos (Ἰσαάκιος Ἄγγελος)
Succession: Rebellion
Deaths:
25 January 1204 (age 47), Constantinople
 Possibly shock or poison

Name: Alexios III Angelos (Ἀλέξιος Ἄγγελος)
Succession: Rebellion, elder brother of Isaac II
Deaths: 1211 (age 58), in captivity in the  Empire of Nicaea

Name:
Isaac II Angelos (Ἰσαάκιος Ἄγγελος)
 (second reign)
Succession: Restored to the throne by the  Fourth Crusade  alongside his son Alexios IV
Deaths:
25 January 1204 (age 47), Constantinople
 Possibly shock or poison

Name: Alexios IV Angelos (Ἀλέξιος Ἄγγελος)
Succession: Raised to the throne by the  Fourth Crusade  alongside his father Isaac II

Name: Alexios V Doukas (Ἀλέξιος Δούκας ὁ Μούρτζουφλος)
Succession: Coup in the Imperial Palace, son-in-law of Alexios III
Deaths:
December 1204 (age 64), Constantinople
 Captured by crusaders of the newly founded  Latin Empire  and publicly executed

Name: Theodore I Laskaris (Θεόδωρος Λάσκαρις)
Succession: His brother  Constantine Laskaris  was elected emperor by the citizens of Constantinople on the day the city fell to the Crusaders; he later fled to  Nicaea , where Theodore organized the Greek resistance to the Latins. Proclaimed emperor after Constantine's death in 1205, Theodore was crowned only in 1208.

Name: John III Doukas Vatatzes (Ἰωάννης Δούκας Βατάτζης)
Succession: Son-in-law of Theodore I

Name: Theodore II Laskaris (Θεόδωρος Λάσκαρις)
Succession: Son of John III

Name: John IV Laskaris (Ἰωάννης Λάσκαρις)
Succession: Son of Theodore II
Deaths:
c. 1305 (age 55), Constantinople
 Blinded and imprisoned by successor in 1261, died in captivity

Name: Michael VIII Palaiologos (Μιχαὴλ Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Senior emperor and regent of John IV Laskaris, grandnephew of John III by marriage and great-grandson of Alexios III

Name: Andronikos II Palaiologos (Ἀνδρόνικος Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of Michael VIII

Name: Michael IX Palaiologos (Μιχαήλ Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of Andronikos II, reigned alongside him as co-emperor with full imperial style

Name: Andronikos III Palaiologos (Ἀνδρόνικος Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of Michael IX, named co-emperor in 1316 and rival emperor since 1321. Deposed his grandfather Andronikos II in 1328 and reigned as sole emperor

Name: John V Palaiologos (Ἰωάννης Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of Andronikos III

Name:
John VI Kantakouzenos (Ἰωάννης Καντακουζηνός)
 with 
 Matthew Kantakouzenos (Ματθαίος Ασάνης Καντακουζηνός)
Succession: Maternal relative of the Palaiologi, declared co-emperor by John V in 1341 and recognized as senior emperor in 1347 following a civil war. Appointed his son Matthew as co-emperor in 1353
Deaths: 15 June 1383 (aged 90 or 91), deposed and in exile as a monk in the  Peloponnese , Matthew was defeated in 1357 and later served as the governor of the  Morea  until his death on the same day as his father

Name: Andronikos IV Palaiologos (Ἀνδρόνικος Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of John V, co-emperor since 1352, deposed his father John V in 1376

Name:
John V Palaiologos (Ἰωάννης Παλαιολόγος)
 (second reign)
Succession: Restored to the throne after overthrowing his son Andronikos IV

Name: John VII Palaiologos (Ἰωάννης Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Rebellion, son and co-emperor of Andronikos IV, deposed his grandfather John V

Name:
John V Palaiologos (Ἰωάννης Παλαιολόγος)
 (third reign)
Succession: Restored to the throne after overthrowing his grandson John VII

Name:
Manuel II Palaiologos (Μανουὴλ Παλαιολόγος)
 with 
 John VII Palaiologos (Ἰωάννης Παλαιολόγος)
 and 
 Andronikos V Palaiologos (Ἀνδρόνικος Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of John V, co-emperor since 1373. John VII Palaiologos, who previously usurped the throne in 1390, was proclaimed co-emperor in 1403, keeping the title until his death in 1408. John VII also proclaimed his son, Andronikos V, co-emperor but Andronikos died before his father, in 1407. The imperial status of John and Andronikos was purely honorary.
Deaths:
21 July 1425 (age 75), Constantinople
 John died 22 September 1408 at  Thessaloniki , Andronikos died aged 7 on September 24th, 1407.

Name: John VIII Palaiologos (Ἰωάννης Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of Manuel II, co-emperor since 1416

Name: Constantine XI Palaiologos (Κωνσταντῖνος Δραγάσης Παλαιολόγος)
Succession: Son of Manuel II
Deaths:
29 May 1453 (age 48), Constantinople
 Refused to surrender Constantinople to the  Ottoman  sultan  Mehmed II  and died fighting during the  final Ottoman attack
